Graphical abstract MCM-41-supported bimetallic Pd-Pt prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method were applied as hydrotreating catalysts for the partial hydrogenation of soybean oil-derived biodiesel into partially hydrogenated fatty acid methyl esters (H-FAME) for use in high blends. The catalytic performance and sulfur resistance of the prepared Pd-Pt/MCM-41 catalysts were strongly associated with the Pd/Pt weight ratio. When H-FAME was synthesized at 100 °C and 0.4 MPa of H2 for 4 h, the 1 wt.% Pd-Pt/MCM-41 (1:1) showed high hydrogenation activity (turnover frequency of 195 h−1 and rate constant of 3.97 × 10−1 h−1gcat−1) with the lowest degree of oversaturation of 4.8 at high conversion of C18:2, and strong resistance to the sulfur species as a poison added to the feedstock. Their high catalytic performance should be related to the suitable size of bimetallic Pd-Pt nanoparticles with a balance of electronic properties, which is supported by the X-ray diffraction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy results. Keywords Partial hydrogenation MCM-41 Noble metals Sulfur tolerance Pd–Pt alloy Rate constant 1 Introduction Fatty acid methyl esters (FAME), also called biodiesel fuel (BDF), have been widely blended with petrodiesel to reduce CO2 emissions in the transport sector [1]. It has been reported that BDF with similar fuel properties, such as cetane number and viscosity, to those of petrodiesel is a safe and secure biofuel for conventional diesel engines if the blending ratio of BDF and petrodiesel is lower than ∼5 vol% [2]. However, recent reports have demonstrated that the conventional diesel engine can be damaged by high blends, which are formulated by low-quality BDF and are generally defined as a blended fuel with a FAME concentration of 7 vol% or higher [3–8]. This is presumably caused by the poor oxidation stability and cold flow property of low-quality BDF, which is caused by improper compositions of FAME and impurities. However, the Ministry of Energy (MoE) of Thailand has targeted high blends as new fuel supply for use in the transport sector. The Alternative Energy Development Plan 2015 (AEDP2015), as legislated by MoE, has attempted to increase the blending ratio of palm oil-derived BDF and petrodiesel to 10 % by 2026 and 20 % by 2036, from the current ratio of 7 % [9–11]. For the safety and security of high blends, it is imperative to develop new technology to upgrade conventional BDFs to high-quality BDFs with suitable fuel and cold-flow properties, which can be formulated with petrodiesel for use in high blends. Hydrogenated FAME (H-FAME), which is a high-quality BDF enriched with monounsaturated FAME (mono-FAME) with high oxidation stability and good cold flow properties can be synthesized by partial hydrogenation of different kinds of conventional BDFs [12–16]. In the synthesis of H-FAME, the polyunsaturated FAME (poly-FAME) is selectively hydrogenated to mono-FAME over the supported metal catalysts, especially Pd, under optimal conditions, which reaction is significantly associated with the structural property and hydrogenation nature of supported metal catalysts [16–18]. Unlike the hydrogenation of fatty acids over the supported Ni catalysts in the industry, the supported noble metals, such as Pd, yield higher hydrogenation activity in the synthesis of H-FAME [12,14,19–21]. However, the deactivation of supported noble metals by a small amount of sulfur species present in the BDF was reported [22]. The nature and concentration of sulfur species naturally presented in the conventional BDFs are strongly related to the feedstock oils or fats. For example, the compositions and impurities of vegetable oils can be significantly varied via soil conditions for growth. A previous report showed that the soybean oils contained around 5–6 ppm of sulfur content [23], which are found in a variety of natural sulfur compounds [24]. The sulfur species originally existed in the commercial BDFs can strongly adsorb on the supported Pd catalysts, which causes catalyst deactivation. Therefore, it is necessary to develop new supported Pd catalysts with high performance and sulfur resistance for the synthesis of H-FAME derived from these sulfur-containing BDFs [25]. The deactivation of supported Pd catalysts during the synthesis of H-FAME can be associated with the adsorption of sulfur on the Pd surfaces through a strong S–Pd bonding which significantly depends on the acidity of the support, and the size and electronic property of Pd particles [26]. Recent studies have attempted to prepare new supported Pd catalysts with enhanced activity and sulfur tolerance level by tuning the structural property of supports and the Pd particles as aforementioned [27]. Yasuda et al. found that the Pd/Pt ratio strongly influenced the activity and the sulfur tolerance of Pd–Pt/USY catalysts for the hydrogenation of tetralin in the presence of dibenzothiophene (DBT) [28]. It is likely that the electronic state of bimetallic Pd–Pt surface can be tuned by its composition and support, resulting in different interactions between the reactant molecules and metal surfaces [29–31]. As a result, the supported bimetallic Pd–Pt catalysts may show higher activity and sulfur resistance than the supported monometallic Pd or Pt catalyst in hydrotreating reactions in the presence of sulfur contamination [32]. In this study, the MCM-41-supported bimetallic Pd–Pt catalysts were prepared by incipient impregnation method and applied in the partial hydrogenation of soybean oil-derived BDF to produce high-quality H-FAME for the first time. The influences of Pd/Pt ratio and structural property on the hydrogenation ability and sulfur resistance of MCM-41-supported Pt-Pd catalysts were discussed. The optimal conditions for preparation of high-quality H-FAME over the prepared catalysts were comprehensive discussed. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Materials The soybean oil used for biodiesel synthesis was bought from the Thai Vegetable Oil Public Company Limited. Methanol (ACS grade) was bought from Honeywell-Burdick and Jackson, and potassium hydroxide (KOH; 85 %) was purchased from RCI Labscan Limited. Other chemical reagents were n-heptane (analytical reagent grade), obtained from Fisher Scientific, and sodium sulphate anhydrous (Na2SO4; 99 %), which was bought from Ajax Finechem Pty. Ltd. Allyl isothiocyanate (CH2CHCH2NCS, Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd.) was used as an additional sulfur compound in the biodiesel feedstock. Pd(NH3)4Cl2×H2O (Pd:40.16 %), and Pt(NH3)4Cl2·xH2O (Pt:56.48 %), purchased from N.E. Chemcat Corporation, Japan, were used as a Pd and Pt precursors, consecutively. The hydrophilic fumed silica (SiO2; > 99.8 %) as a silica source of MCM-41 was purchased from Evonik (SEA) Pte. Ltd. Hexadecyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (C16TAB; >98 %) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. 2.2 Preparation of supported Pd–Pt catalysts The mesoporous silica MCM-41 was synthesized by the procedures described in a previous report [17] using fumed silica as a silica source with the assistance of microwave irradiation. Briefly, 0.848 g of C16TAB was dissolved in the mixture of 970 μL of 2 M NaOH solution and 12.571 g of deionized water (DW) under stirring. To this solution, 0.466 g of fumed silica was added under stirring for 1 h. The resulting gel with a composition of Si : 0.3 C16TAB : 0.25 NaOH : 90 H2O was heated at 70 °C for 5 h under microwave irradiation (500 W). The resulting solid was filtered, washed with DW to remove bromine ions, and dried at 105 °C overnight. The template was removed by calcining the as-made MCM-41 at 500 °C for 6 h using a heating rate of 0.5 °C/min in air. A series of MCM-41-supported Pd–Pt catalysts with a total metal loading of 1 wt.% and various Pd:Pt weight ratios of 3:1, 1:1 and 1:3, were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method. The catalysts are denoted as Pd–Pt(3:1)/MCM-41, Pd–Pt(1:1)/MCM-41, and Pd–Pt(1:3)/MCM-41, the numbers in parentheses represent the weight ratio of Pd/Pt in the prepared catalysts. The precursor solutions were prepared by dissolving Pd(NH3)4Cl2×H2O (Pd:40.16 %) in an appropriate amount of DW. The precursor solutions were then impregnated on the MCM-41 support and aged for 24 h. The impregnated samples were dried for 6 h followed by calcined at 400 °C with a heating rate of 0.5 °C/min for 2 h under an oxygen flow. The Pd-impregnated MCM-41 samples were then impregnated by another precursor solution of Pt(NH3)4Cl2·xH2O (Pt:56.48 %) and aged, dried, and calcined based on the aforementioned procedures. As a result, the MCM-41-supported Pd–Pt catalysts were prepared. The MCM-41-supported monometallic Pt or Pd catalysts with a metal loading of 1 wt.% were prepared by the same procedures and used as reference catalysts. 2.3 Catalyst characterization N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were employed in a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 MP surface area analyzer. Before the measurement, the samples were outgassed under vacuum at 250 °C overnight to eliminate the volatile species and physically adsorbed water. The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The pore volume was accumulated up to a P/P0 ratio of 0.994. The pore size distribution was analyzed by a Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) desorption method. Small-angle X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded by a Rigaku TTRAX III diffractometer using a Cu Kα radiation (1.5405 Å) as a light source at 50 kV and 300 mA. All of the small-angle XRD patterns were recorded in the 2θ range of 2–10° using a step size of 0.01 and scanning speed of 1° s−1. Wide-angle XRD patterns were collected over a 2θ range of 5–90°, step size of 0.01, and scanning speed of 5° s−1 by a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα at 40 kV and 30 mA. The pulse CO chemisorption was performed on an Ohkura Riken Model R6015 instrument, which provided the metal dispersion and particle size of the prepared catalysts. The stoichiometry of CO to either Pd or Pt was assumed to be unity. The sample was reduced at 300 °C for 2 h using pure H2 flow (30 mL/min) with a ramp rate of 5 °C/min, and then purged with helium before the measurement. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were acquired by a JEOL JEM-2010 model instrument operated at an accelerating voltage of 120 kV in bright-field mode. The samples were dispersed in ethanol under ultrasonic irradiation. The suspension was carefully dropped on the carbon-coated copper grids for TEM measurement. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were measured using a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD photoelectron spectrometer, which provided the chemical environments of the prepared catalysts. All the XPS measurements were carried out under a high vacuum (< 5 × 10−7 torr). A monochromatic Al Kα radiation was used as a light source. The binding energy (BE) was calibrated based on the C 1s band at 284.6 eV. 2.4 Transesterification of soybean oil with methanol First, 180 g of soybean oil (SO) was heated in a 500-mL three-necked round-bottom flask at 60 °C. To start the transesterification, 16.9 g of KOH-methanol mixed solution was added and stirred (300 rpm) at 60 °C for 1 h. The methanol/oil molar ratio was 9 and the KOH/Oil ratio was 1 wt.%. After transesterification, the SO-BDF was obtained by the removal of glycerin and washed with 60 °C DW several times until the pH value was approximately 7, then sealed in a glass bottle with Na2SO4. 2.5 Synthesis of SO-derived H-FAME A stainless-steel semi-batch reaction system was utilized to study the hydrogenation activity and selectivity of the MCM-41-supported Pd–Pt catalysts during the partial hydrogenation of SO-BDF at 100 °C and 0.4 MPa of H2 to form H-FAME. The samples of Pd–Pt impregnated on the MCM-41 were reduced by a H2 flow (100 mL/min) at 200 °C for 2 h using a heating rate of 5 °C/min before use in the catalytic testing. In a typical reaction, a 150 mL of SO-BDF (130.4 g) and 1.3 g of catalysts were mixed in the reactor and purged by N2 twice. The stirring rate was maintained at 500 rpm and the H2 flow at 150 mL/min. At the specific time (every 30 min during the reaction period), a small portion of hydrotreated products was taken and analyzed by a Hewlett-Packard gas chromatograph (GC) 5890 Series II instrument equipped with a DB-WAX fused-silica capillary column (a 0.2-μm film of polyimide coating, 100 m in length, 0.25 mm in internal diameter) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The GC analysis conditions were as follows: the carrier gas was He (99.99 %) with a flow rate of 70 mL/min, and 0.2 μL of each sample was injected under an injector temperature of 200 °C and detector temperature of 230 °C with a split ratio of 75:1. The turnover frequency (TOF) of prepared catalysts in the synthesis of H-FAME was calculated by the following equation [33]: (1) T O F ( h -1 ) = I n i t i a l r a t e ( A m o u n t o f P d ) ( D i s p e r s i o n ) where the initial rate was calculated by dividing the molar fraction of poly-FAME consumed by the catalyst weight and reaction time at a C18:2 conversion of less than 20 %. The dispersion of metal was determined by the CO chemisorption technique. Kinetic analysis of the prepared catalysts in the synthesis of H-FAME was further carried out, where the rate constants for hydrogenation of poly-FAME (included C18:3 and C18:2 components) into mono-FAME (C18:1) were simulated using the equation below. (2) A → k 1 , k 2 B where k1 is the rate constant for the SO-BDF without additional sulfur species and k2 is the rate constant for that with additional sulfur species. The rate equations for hydrogenation of poly-FAME (shortly termed A) are enumerated in Eqs. (3)–(5) based on the first-order irreversible reaction [22]. (3) r A = d A d t = - k 1,2 A (4) ln A - l n A 0 = - k t (5) ln A 0 A = k t A plot of ln(A0/A) as a function of time (t) using the first-order rate equation yields a straight line with a slope of k. The experimental data were then fitted by a linear and polynomial regression function using a Polymath 6.1 software (Polymath Software, Professional use version, SWREG Digital River). The rate constants of k1 and k2 were obtained by Polymath curve fitting with the maximum goodness-of-fit, and the correlation coefficient (R2) should be close to 1. 2.6 Sulfur tolerance test Allyl isothiocyanate (CH2CHCH2NCS) was added in the SO-BDF feedstock to study the sulfur tolerance level of the MCM-41-supported Pd–Pt catalysts in the synthesis of SO-BDF. Note that the sulfur content originally presented in the SO-BDF was 1.2 ppm. The additional 2 ppm allyl isothiocyanate was added to SO-BDF, resulting in a sulfur-containing SO-BDF with a total sulfur content of 3.4 ppm. The procedures for the conversion of sulfur-containing SO-BDF to H-FAME and for the GC analysis were the same as those described in Section 2.5. The influence of sulfur species on the kinetic behavior of prepared catalysts in the synthesis of H-FAME was also studied by fitting the experimental data via Polymath software. 2.7 Biodiesel analysis Oxidative stability was analyzed by a Metrohm 743 Rancimat instrument (Herisau, Switzerland) according to the European standard UNE-EN 14212:2003 method. Air flow (10,000 mL/h) was bubbled to 7.5 g of SO-BDF and corresponding H-FAME at 110 °C using a temperature correction factor (ΔT) of 1.6 °C. The volatile oxidation products, which were formed by oxidation of SO-BDF or H-FAME, were dissolved in a 60 mL DW, of which the conductivity varied over the recording time. The induction time (h) was obtained by extrapolating through the inflection point. The cloud point was measured by an ISL Automatic Cloud & Pour Point Analyzer (CPP 5 Gs) based on the standard method of ASTM D2500. The standard test method ASTM D5453-16e1 was used for analysis of total sulfur content of SO-BDF and H-FAME using Analytik jena Model EA5000 elemental analyzer instrument. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of MCM-41 used as a supporting material displayed a Types Ⅳ isotherm with a steep hysteresis loop at P/P0 region of 0.25–0.4, which is a characteristic feature of MCM-41 mesoporous silica materials (Fig. 1 A). The specific BET surface area, total pore volume and pore size diameter of MCM-41 were 1,385 m2/g, 1.02 cm3/g, and 2.5 nm, respectively. For the MCM-41-supported Pd–Pt catalysts (Table 1 ), the specific BET surface areas and total pore volumes decreased, owing to the collapse of the ordering pore structure by the acidic metal precursor solution and calcination treatment. The BJH pore size-distribution plot, which was obtained from the N2 desorption branch (in Fig. 2 ), confirms this finding. However, these MCM-41-supported Pd–Pt catalysts gave higher surface area and pore volume than conventional Pd–Pt/zeolites, probably due to its open pore structure [34]. Fig. 3 shows the small-angle XRD patterns of the MCM-41-supported Pd–Pt catalysts, in comparison to MCM-41 support, which showed strong diffraction peaks of 2D-hexagonal p6mm pore structure at 2.4–6.3° [35,36]. The (100) diffraction peak of MCM-41-supported Pd–Pt catalysts was broadened and slightly shifted to relatively high 2θ region, due the ordering pore structure was collapsed to form randomly-distributed and accessible pores [37]. The wide-angle diffraction patterns of the MCM-41 support, monometallic catalysts, and bimetallic catalysts were also recorded in the 2θ range of 5–90° (Fig. 4 ). Only a broad diffraction peak at 2θ = 25° was observed in Pd/MCM-41 catalyst, corresponding to amorphous silica framework of MCM-41 [17,38]. No diffraction peaks related to Pd species can be found, indicating that the amorphous Pd species was formed in the Pd/MCM-41 catalyst [13,17]. For the Pt/MCM-41 catalyst, several diffraction peaks corresponding to cubic Pt particles can be observed. The representative XRD patterns of the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 with various Pd/Pt ratios show another series of diffraction peaks at 42.5-43°, 49-50°, 70-71°, and 84-83°, which correspond to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes, respectively. It is specially noticed that the (111) planes of Pd–Pt(3:1)/MCM-41, Pd–Pt(1:1)/MCM-41, and Pd–Pt(1:3)/MCM-41 can be observed at 42.8°, 42.9°, and 42.7°, respectively, which are located between the monometallic Pt/MCM-41 catalyst (Fig. 4) and monometallic Pd species reported in the literatures [39–42]. This observation indicates that bimetallic Pd–Pt species were existed in the Pd-Pt/MCM-41 catalysts. In Fig. 5 A, the TEM images show that the MCM-41 support contained regular channeling pores of 2D-hexagnoal pore structure, which is consistent with the XRD results. In Fig. 5B and C, the Pt and Pd nanoparticles are clearly observed for the Pd/MCM-41 and Pt/MCM-41 catalysts, whose sizes are close to the results of the CO chemisorption. Regarding the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalysts (Fig. 5D–F), relatively large bimetallic Pd–Pt particles dispersed on the SiO2 matrix were observed, and the size analyses were close to the result of CO chemisorption. This indicates that the bimetallic Pd–Pt species tend to form relatively large alloy particles than the monometallic Pt or Pd species. Pd 3d and Pt 4f core-level XPS spectra of monometallic (Pd/MCM-41 and Pt/MCM-41) and bimetallic Pd–Pt/MCM-41 were investigated by the XPS technique. The Pd 3d spectra recorded for mono- and bimetallic catalysts show a typical Pd 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 doublet consisting of two overlapping components, indicating the coexistence of Pd0 and PdO species, which may have formed from the oxidation of Pd0 during the solid exposure to the atmospheric air [13,43,44]. The combined line with the dominant line of metallic state (Pd0) is displayed in Fig. 6 A. The position of the signals with lower binding energy (BE) values in the 334.1–335.8-eV region is assigned to metallic Pd 3d5/2, while the signals with higher BE values in the 339.3–341.1-eV region can be attributed to the metallic Pd 3d3/2 (referred to the National Institute of Standards and Technology database). Monometallic Pd/MCM-41 catalyst presents a BE at 335.7 eV and 341.1 eV for Pd0 3d5/2 and Pd0 3d3/2, respectively. The monometallic Pt/MCM-41 catalyst shows two peaks in the Pt 4f spectrum at BE of 71.9 eV and 75.3 eV, which are consistent with the zero-valence state of Pt metal species for the Pt 4f7/2 and Pt 4f5/2 core levels, respectively. The addition of Pt to Pd/MCM-41 influences the XPS spectra of Pd, i.e., this modification was accompanied by a pronounced shift in both Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 with respect to monometallic Pd/MCM-41 catalyst (Fig. 6A). Meanwhile, the XPS spectra of Pt 4f for bimetallic Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalysts demonstrate an obvious shift with respect to monometallic analogue Pt/MCM-41 (Fig. 6B). The difference in electronegativity between the Pd and Pt elements is associated with the shift of BE. A higher electronegative element (Pt, 2.28) will draw electrons from the lower electronegative element (Pd, 2.2), then the increased electron density around Pt would cause to the downshift of the d-band center due to partial filling of the Pt 5d bands, and shifts its BE to lower values. Such changes in the electronic state of supported Pd and Pt in bimetallic Pd–Pt system indicated that there is an interaction between Pd and Pt in all Pd–Pt/MCM-41 samples [45–49]. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalysts in the synthesis of H-FAME The prepared Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalysts with various Pd:Pt ratios of 3:1, 1:1, and 1:3 were used as the hydrotreating catalysts for synthesis of H-FAME under a mild condition (100 °C, 4 bars of H2 pressure, 500 rpm stirring rate), in comparison to the monometallic Pd or Pt/MCM-41 catalysts. The catalyst weight was held at 1 wt.%. The hydrotreated products were specifically taken during the reaction period of 30−240 min with an interval of 30 min. The main components of SO-BDF were methyl linoleate (C18:2, 51.29 %), cis-methyl oleate (cis-C18:1, 26.01 %), methyl palmitate (C16:0, 11.11 %), methyl linolenate (C18:3, 5.12 %), and methyl stearate (C18:0, 3.84 %), which accounted for approximately 99 % of the total FAME components. In the study, the compositions of C18 components, including C18:0, cis-C18:1, trans-C18:1, C18:2, and C18:3, of H-FAME over the prepared catalysts as a functional of light and deep hydrogenation were first discussed in Table 2 . The light and deep hydrogenation were defined when the C18:2 conversions were reached 20 % and 90 %, respectively. For H-FAME synthesized by the monometallic catalysts, Pd/MCM-41 gave the lowest amount of C18:3 content for the light hydrogenation, whereas the reverse is true for the Pt/MCM-41 catalyst. We particularly interested in the deep hydrogenation of BDF catalyzed by the prepared catalysts into H-FAME enriched with mono-FAME components. In other words, the poly-FAME is selectively hydrogenated to form mono-FAME and its fully hydrogenation to form saturated fatty acid methyl esters should be prevented. Under deep hydrogenation conditions, the Pd/MCM-41 catalyst showed lower activity in the synthesis of H-FAME than the bimetallic Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalysts, which the C18:3 component can be completely converted to the corresponding hydrogenated analogues. In addition, the Pt/MCM-41 catalyst can only give a 51 % conversion of C18:2 even after the reaction was carried out at 100 ℃ and 0.4 MPa of H2 for 4 h. The highest C18:2 conversion of Pt/MCM-41 catalyst is 51 %, therefore, it cannot be compared under C18:2 conversion of 90 %. The results show that the conversion of C18:3 components increased in an order of Pd–Pt(3:1)/MCM-41 < Pd/MCM-41 ∼ Pd–Pt(1:3)/MCM-41 < Pd–Pt(1:1)/MCM-41, indicating that the Pd–Pt(1:1)/MCM-41 catalyst gives the highest activity in the synthesis of H-FAME. A similar trend is observed for the isomerization of cis-monounsaturated FAME component to trans-form analogues, which is highly associated with the hydrogenation activity of the prepared catalysts. Fig. 7 A shows the TOF determined at a C18:2 conversion of 20 % as a functional of the Pd:Pt weight ratio. A volcano curve was observed, and the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with a Pd/Pt weight ratio of 1 yielded the highest TOF value in the synthesis of H-FAME. The TOF value was decreased when the Pd/Pt ratio was less than or greater than 1. Furthermore, the TOF values of the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalysts are much higher than those of Pd/MCM-41 and Pt/MCM-41 catalysts. A similar phenomenon is observed for the order of the rate constants for the prepared bimetallic catalysts using SO-BDF as a feedstock with no added sulfur species (k1 ), in the sequence of Pd–Pt(1:1)/MCM-41 > Pd–Pt(1:3)/MCM-41 > Pd–Pt(3:1)/MCM-41 with 3.97, 2.96, and 2.91 (×10−1  h-1gcat -1), respectively. This is likely due to the synergic effect of Pd–Pt alloys in the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst, which is suitable for the partial hydrogenation of SO-BDF to the corresponding H-FAME. Li et al. [50] reported that the bimetallic Pt-Ni and Pt-Co catalysts gave higher activity in hydrogenation of 2(5 H)-furanone to γ-butyrolactone (GBL) than the monometallic Pt, Ni, and Co catalysts, due to higher binding energy of the reactant molecules. The XPS results showed that the Pd0 3d3/2 and Pd0 3d5/2 BEs of the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalysts are observed in the range of 340.3–341.6 eV and 335.0–336.0 eV, respectively, which are lower than the Pd/MCM-41. Moreover, the lower Pt0 4f5/2 (74.4–74.8 eV) and Pt0 4f7/2 (71.0–71.3 eV) BEs of the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalysts are observed as compared to the BE of Pt/MCM-41. In other words, the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalysts contained bimetallic Pd–Pt alloy nanoparticles, which are supported by the results of XRD patterns. The present study showed that the bimetallic Pd–Pt nanoparticles are highly active for partial hydrogenation of SO-BDF to H-FAME, particularly for the Pd/Pt ratio of 1. To further evaluate the hydrogenation selectivity of the prepared catalysts in the synthesis of H-FAME, the degree of oversaturation (DOO) was calculated by the Eq. (6), where the C18:0 fraction formed was divided by the C18:1 fraction in the H-FAME [17]. (6) D e g r e e o f o v e r s a t u r a t i o n % = C18:0 in product-C18:0 in feed Total amounts of C18:1 in product ×100 Fig. 7C shows the DOO value as a function of Pd/Pt ratio. The S-shaped curve over the prepared catalysts with various Pd/Pt ratios is observed and the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with a Pd/Pt ratio of 1 give the lowest DOO values for the C18:2 conversions at 20–90 %. Pd–Pt(1:1)/MCM-41 catalyst with a particle size of 6–7 nm and 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 BEs of 340.3 eV and 335.0 eV, respectively, is apparently good for partial hydrogenation of SO-BDF to H-FAME with higher selectivity toward mono-FAME. It is presumably due to the proper adsorption strength of reactant molecules, such as, C18:2, over the alloy Pd–Pt surfaces. Similarly, the desorption of hydrogenated component, such as C18:1, over the alloy Pd–Pt surfaces can be facilitated. As a result, the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with proper Pd/Pt ratio of 1 and suitable particle size give the highest activity and selectivity than other analogues catalysts with higher or lower Pd/Pt ratios and improper particle sizes. 3.3 Sulfur tolerance of the Pd, Pt, and Pd–Pt catalysts It is known that the sulfur species are naturally presented in the SO-BDF, which are poisoned to the noble metal catalysts [51]. The sulfur tolerance level of the prepared catalysts in the synthesis of H-FAME was further studied by adding a small amount of sulfur species to the feedstock. The allyl isothiocyanate (CH2CHCH2NCS, 2 ppm) as a standard sulfur compound in the BDFs reported previously was added into SO-BDF [52]. Fig. 8 A shows the C18:2 conversions over the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with a Pd/Pt ratio of 1 in the synthesis of H-FAME at 100 °C and 0.4 MPa H2 for 4 h, in comparison to the monometallic Pd or Pt/MCM-41 catalyst. The results show that the addition of sulfur species has little influence on the activities of Pd/MCM-41 and Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalysts, corresponding to high sulfur resistance level. However, the activity of Pt/MCM-41 catalyst was dropped significantly, due the serious poison of sulfur species on the Pt surface. Table 3 shows that that the initial rates and TOF values over the Pd/MCM-41 and Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalysts are slightly decreased when 2 ppm of sulfur was added to the feedstock. The significant decreases in the initial rate (Δinitial rate, 66.7 %) and TOF (ΔTOF, 65 %) was observed for the Pt/MCM-41 catalyst. Similar observation is observed for the decrease of rate constant (Δk) which increased in an order Pd–Pt(1:1)/MCM-41 < Pd/MCM-41 < Pt/MCM-41. It is obvious that the prepared catalyst containing Pd species give higher sulfur tolerance level than that without Pd species [53]. The influence of the sulfur species on the compositions of H-FAME over the prepared catalysts is discussed next. In the synthesis of H-FAME, the cis-monounsaturated FAME can be converted into the trans-form analogue over the prepared catalysts, whose amount is usually proportional to the hydrogenation activity of the catalytically active sites. In this study, we would like to specifically discuss the amount of cis and trans-monounsaturated components in the H-FAME. In general, the cis-form C18:1 plays higher cold-flow properties than the trans-form analogues, because of its lower crystallization point [43]. Table 2 shows that the H-FAME over the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with a Pd/Pt ratio of 1 contains highest C18:1 with low C18:0 and C18:2, and no C18:3. However, we found that the trans-C18:1 component in the H-FAME over the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with Pd/Pt ratios of 1 are higher than those over the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 with other ratios and the DOO value of Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst is higher than that of other catalysts (Fig. 8C). This is because the deep hydrogenation and the fast isomerization of cis-C18:1 to trans-form analogues can be facilitated over the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with a Pd/Pt ratio of 1, due to strong hydrogenation ability of metallic Pd–Pt alloy nanoparticles (Figs. 7B and 8). However, the trans-C18:1 component in the H-FAME over the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with a Pd/Pt ratio of 1 can be decreased when a small amount of the sulfur species was added to the feedstock (Fig. 8B). Meanwhile, the DOO value is largely decreased (Fig. 8C). It is probably because the sulfur species are selectively adsorbed on the catalytically active sites with strong hydrogenation activity of the prepared Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with a Pd/Pt ratio of 1. As a result, the deep hydrogenation and the isomerization of cis-C18:1 to trans-form analogues can be hindered. While, the hydrogenation of C18:3 and C18:2 to C18:1 is not significantly affected by the adsorption of sulfur on the prepared Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with a Pd/Pt ratio of 1. This suggestion is supported by the higher k2 number as shown in Table 3, corresponding to selective hydrogenation of C18:3 and C18:2 to C18:1 of the SO-BDF with additional sulfur species. The highest k2 value of 3.32 × 10−1  h-1gcat -1 is found over the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with a Pd/Pt ratio of 1, which decreases only 16.4 % from the k1 . It is an alternative way to turn the composition of H-FAME over the prepared Pd–Pt catalyst with a Pd/Pt ratio of 1, giving a H-FAME product with desirable FAME composition. 3.4 Cold-flow properties of SO-BDF and H-FAME According to the H-FAME technology developed through Thailand–Japan collaboration SATREPS PJ of “Innovation on production and automotive utilization of biofuels from non-food biomass” (FY2010-FY2015), the cloud point of B100 BDF should be lower than 16 °C in Thailand [54]. In addition, the oxidative stability of biodiesel must meet the specifications of EN14214:2012 standard and Thailand standard, which are 8 h and 10 h, respectively, based on the requirement of Department of Energy Business, MoE of Thailand. Table 4 shows the cold-flow properties of SO-BDF and corresponding H-FAME over the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with a Pd/Pt ratio of 1 at 100 °C, and 0.4 MPa of H2 for 4 h, comparison to those of other analogue catalysts, synthesized by using SO-BDF without and with adding allyl isothiocyanate. SO-BDF has good cold-flow properties and poor oxidation stability (0.6 h) due to large amounts of C18:3 and C18:2, which cannot meet the international fuel standards. In contrast, all the H-FAMEs give very high oxidation stability due to low amounts of C18:3 and C18:2, and high amount of C18:1 although the cold-flow properties are slightly higher than 16 °C due to too much amount of C18:0, which is the recommended number for ASEAN countries. It is specifically noted that H-FAME synthesized by the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with a Pd/Pt ratio of 1 and using sulfur-containing SO-BDF as the feedstock contains high oxidation stability and suitable cold-flow properties due to its suitable FAME compositions, especially for cis-C18:1 component. The result shows again that H-FAME with good fuel property and cold flow properties can be easily prepared by the Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with a Pd/Pt ratio of 1 under mild reaction conditions with the assistance of small amount of sulfur species to hinder the strong hydrogenation sites. 4 Conclusions Partial hydrogenation of SO-BDF over the MCM-41-supported bimetallic Pd–Pt catalyst with 1 wt.% of metal loading and a Pd/Pt weight ratio of 1 was studied under a mild condition, resulting in H-FAME, a new type of high-quality BDF, and compared to the reference materials with only monometallic Pd or Pt sites and its analogues with 1 wt.% of metal loading and various Pd/Pt weight ratios other than 1. The Pd–Pt(1:1)/MCM-41 with an optimal Pd/Pt weight ratio showed higher activity in the synthesis of H-FAME and better selectivity toward mono-FAME than the reference materials and analogues. In addition, the Pd–Pt(1:1)/MCM-41 catalyst also gave higher sulfur resistance than those monometallic counterparts, because of a synergic effect of the Pd–Pt alloys with proper particle size. Because the sulfur species were presumably adsorbed on the Pd–Pt sites with high hydrogenation ability, the sulfur-poisoned Pd–Pt/MCM-41 catalyst with suppressed hydrogenation ability was found to yield higher cis-monounsaturated FAME selectivity and lower saturated FAME, which was a new method for synthesis of H-FAME enriched with cis-monounsaturated FAME as the favorite component for high blends with improved oxidative stability and suitable cold flow properties. coredata.dc:description: MCM-41-supported bimetallic Pd-Pt prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method were applied as hydrotreating catalysts for the partial hydrogenation of soybean oil-derived biodiesel into partially hydrogenated fatty acid methyl esters (H-FAME) for use in high blends. The catalytic performance and sulfur resistance of the prepared Pd-Pt/MCM-41 catalysts were strongly associated with the Pd/Pt weight ratio. When H-FAME was synthesized at 100 °C and 0.4 MPa of H2 for 4 h, the 1 wt.% Pd-Pt/MCM-41 (1:1) showed high hydrogenation activity (turnover frequency of 195 h−1 and rate constant of 3.97 × 10−1 h−1gcat−1) with the lowest degree of oversaturation of 4.8 at high conversion of C18:2, and strong resistance to the sulfur species as a poison added to the feedstock. Their high catalytic performance should be related to the suitable size of bimetallic Pd-Pt nanoparticles with a balance of electronic properties, which is supported by the X-ray diffraction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy results.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation of MCM-41-supported Pd–Pt catalysts with enhanced activity and sulfur resistance for partial hydrogenation of soybean oil-derived biodiesel fuel
